summary: When Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina), a naïve young woman, is purchased from her impoverished mother by brutish circus strongman Zampanò (Anthony Quinn) to be his wife and partner, she loyally endures her husband's coldness and abuse as they travel the Italian countryside performing together. Soon Zampanò must deal with his jealousy and conflicted feelings about Gelsomina when she finds a kindred spirit in Il Matto (Richard Basehart), the carefree circus fool, and contemplates leaving Zampanò.

reviews.content: Pretty grim stuff by today's standards in terms of how women are treated, even moreso than the other Fellini films I've seen. But it's from a different era. A sad take on the beauty and the beast trope, with good performances and the beginning ingredients of what they call fellini-esqe films. And Giulietta Masina is wonderful.

La Strada is an amazing movie. I love the performances, the story and the set designs. I also enjoy of how the movie is reinventing by focusing on realism instead of the old Hollywood techniques. Overall, La Strada is a one of a kind movie from the Italian state.
fellinis best and one of my all time favorites. the character Gelsomina is one of the greatest characters i can remember seeing.

An unconventional yet captivating friendship -- and sort of romance -- that depicts an excellent contrast between gullible innocence and brute strength, that thanks to Federico Fellini's filmmaking talent and the well-matched leads, it becomes one of the greatest films of postwar Italy.

In Federico Fellini's La Strada, Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina), a young and simple peasant girl, is sold to Zampano (Anthony Quinn), a brutal street entertainer, as his assistant.  Together, they travel the Italian countryside, scrounging to make ends meet and struggling to come to terms with their volatile relationship.  It is an often beautiful and sometimes ugly examination of the meaning of being, filled with striking images, a touching score, and a strong performance from Quinn.  Some will find Masina's performance overbearing at times, but she effectively captures the innocent nature of her character.  The final shot of Zampano on the beach coming to terms with his lot in life is nothing if not memorable.

A very hard to describe movie. It sort of reminded me of "Requiem for a Dream" in the feeling of it.
Very good movie that you will not soon forget.
A classic in sheer boredom. It's a long road to get to the end of this sombre piece. Can't recommend.
It is not like watching a movie but it is like watching a life with all its shades blinking, winking and whimpering to one's own soul.
Yet another film in which Fellini spoils the neorealism with his consummate obsessions over one excellent script. 4/10
Federico Fellini's ‘La Strada' is full of life and friction - stark - an unpragmatic must-see!

From the first moment of the first scene I could tell this was something of quality, I have no idea how but I just could and overall this film is of high quality. It is also very Italian - intense passion, crude roughness and culture all rolled into one - Italy in a nutshell. Unfortunately for me the film was ruined by one thing and that is completely and utterly ruined beyond redemption and that thing was Gelsomina and her acting. The character appeared to have no depth or meaning whatsoever and are we supposed to find her amusing just because she makes funny faces and walks in a funny way. I need a bit more to a character than expression and gait and spent the whole film thinking someone should have really told her that she isn't Charlie Chaplin. She irritated me utterly. I tried to enjoy other parts of the film, which were good but just couldn't because I had to look at her, even when they appeared to be developing another aspect of the film it would then cut to a close up of her making some expression as though completely unaware that we had to watch these painful, over-acted, unnatural contortions, there was no escape. The truest line in the whole film was when she was told she had a face like an artichoke. I actually quite liked the other characters, Zampano included, not that maybe I liked them as people but as characters, cliched admittedly but at least they seemed to have some sort of meaning and authenticity about them and the fool even have something useful to say. They could have done Gelsomina so much better - either the oppressed woman powerless and basically sold into slavery, or the trapped women escaped to take on the free life of a gypsy rover; as it happened they tried both, did neither and any attempt was usually cut short by having to look at her funny faces and ridiculous gait. I don't know much about Chaplin but there must be something about him though I do wonder if this style is better left to silent cinema. All this combined with how they tried to develop the other characters both as individuals and as archetypes meant perhaps this film was trying to do too much which is in credit to its makers and of interest to professional critics and film students but to me just made it unenjoyable. It was a good premise and if they had done more in a Saragossa type style this could have been an 8/9/10 out of 10 film. As it was: 6/10
Possibly the best performances by both Anthony Quinn and Richard Basehart.

La Strada is an early step for Fellini, and though not as fully realized as some of his later work, it's still a step in the right direction. History has chosen this film as one of the premier representatives of a classic dynamic, the innocent youth and the jaded pragmatist. Here, they are each treated with a sense of morbid tragedy, as the former lacks self-sufficiency and the latter is doomed to dissatisfaction and self-loathing. The two leads are exceptionally well-suited to their respective roles, with Masina exuding a wide-eyed naiveté while Quinn brings forth surprising depth from his role, displaying at various points cold indifference, covetousness, and ultimately a consuming regret that forces him to recognize his own cruel nature. Those searching for the layers of subtext that Fellini interjects into his work so often will have a field day with this one, as the simplicity of its overall narrative allows for endless interpretation. More conventionally structured than his later films, La Strada shows the director/writer's strengths in pulling from personal experience to tug the heartstrings. (4/5)
While the plot for La Strada could work well for a light hearted comedy, the multi-layered film ventures into the blackest depths of human emotion.
One of Felini's early - and most troubled - achievements , La Strada manages to balance well its bleaky and beautiful moments contrasting Giuletta Masina and Anthony Quinn performances.

Rarely have I encountered so much of life - and death - packed into one film. Comedy, tragedy, hope, despair, cruelty and love represented by astonishing performances, superb cinematography, a stunning score. A master at work.

Incredible depth to a story I saw as one of victim and abuser, and surprisingly you sympathize with both: the victim because you pity all those who can’t defend themselves, and the abuser because they are trapped in their own misery. Fascinating visuals, incredible acting, spellbinding music, and a must see for all time.
A haunting story and wonderfully acted.

I know this is one of Fellini's most famous movies, but I almost feel like its the song off the greatest hits album that you want to listen to the least. I just feel like it gets bogged down and repetitive. Not one of my favorites.

An early film from the Italian master Federico Fellini. A slightly retarted girl is sold to an entertainer that drifts around streets looking for small crowds to impress people with his iron breaking trick. Gelsomina is not treated nicely as his assistant and she have more downs than ups during her time with Zampanò. When they come to a circus she meets up with a guy she has seen perform before. "The Fool" is very gifted and she likes this man way more than her companion. Naturally the two men argue and she is left pretty sad wondering what to do. People are always treating her bad and she kind of stick up with it - she does not know any better.

This film starts of pretty flat and boring. There is not much of a plot other than the things I mention, but something big happen after the first hour plus or so. This is when the film really gets better for me and I find it easier to enjoy this semi-bizarre film for it's qualities.

Fellini is not one of my favorites, but the three or four I have seen before this one has been good or great. This one is for me somewhere in the middle. I find it a bit overrated and very dated. Some cool transitions, some great shots, but a story with late development and to much repetition in a way - it feels dragged. As a whole and a total it helps a lot with the last 30 minutes or so, where both the characters and the movie change. At also stayed with me for a while - so you can say it's a grower. A good thing.

7.5 out of 10 iron pieces stronger than steel.

La Strada is one of those movies I find tough to endure. It has good acting performances, and it is scripted well. I can’t say that I was ever bored or disengaged by the plot. Yet the film is painful because it’s so hard to watch the struggles of the main character. She is so badly mistreated in every definition of the word, that I can’t help empathizing with her. There are brief moments of lightness and gaiety, but oppression feels like it is always right around the corner. I know there are others who can watch this kind of film and appreciate the authentic realization of the human experience, and I can see why La Strada would be lauded for that accomplishment. I’m simply not built to handle a film where the protagonist is constantly suffering. Also, as I mentioned in my review of A Streetcar Named Desire, this isn’t the time in my life when I can find any entertainment in an abusive relationship. That being said, I still applaud the quality of La Strada. It is a well-constructed film and it has many elements that I’d call great. Sadly, the whole package isn’t appealing to me.

La Strada is an Italian neorealist film by Federico Fellini, meaning it will show people demonstrating resilience in the face of adversity, but it will also be somewhat autobiographical and self-indulgent (although this might not be obvious if you didn't know Fellini's background [although you don't have to know Fellini's background to sense 8 1/2 is self-indulgent]). La Strada walks a tightrope between bittersweet and melodramatic, without ever falling off--a difficult balance Fellini manages well. Fellini's wife, Giulietta Masina, plays an impish female lead who contrasts with Anthony Quinn's brute. Both stars are captivating and highly appealing in their roles.
This is the worst film I have ever seen. Period. I would literally rather watch any other film than have to be put through the agony of viewing La Strada again.
Exceptional cinemaography and moving performances. Probably one of the best films of all time.
Exceptional classic by Fellini about a girl who joins a traveling road show strong man. I cried at the end. Giulietta Masina is just a joy to watch. One of all time favorite movies.

Early Fellini effort is this funny and poignant picture about two different people: one is a brute and the other is a small and caring girl. They fail to communicate but somehow inexplicably they are drawn to each other. It's a heart-wrenching movie with strong performances.

Among all the Fellini's works, this is my favorite. Giulietta Masina is so awesome. It's few of the films where you don't need to understand the words to understand the story. The words seem to be part of the gestures of the actors. Incredible!
Anthony Quinn is a legend.

A true italian classic that explores the almost Chaplin-like body language of Giulietta Masina for comedic value and Anthony Quinn's character for emotional progression. In the end, Fellini created a masterpiece so strong in performances, writing and cinematography that depicts a world that is both cruel and corrosive to the naive way of living.
Exceptional!... Anthony Quinn's brute strongman and Giulietta's tender clown create such a beautiful contrast in this road film. One of the early masterpiece's from Fellini.

La Strada has its strengths mainly the visuals which are great, the directing and acting along with some moving moments and a couple of quite memorable sequences, but the story here is typical and not particularly inspired as are its characters and the film is badly paced and never as emotional or as dramatic as it should have been. It is quite a solid film for sure, but it is also far from a great one as it is so familiar and slight for the most part.

Fellini was a master from the beginning. This film is inventive, complex and strikes many chords amongst humans. The film sound track is all dubbed in two versions, italian and english. I watched the italian with subtitles. This is the kind of film that shows us lessons that are much better learned in cinema than in real life. The poor girl is sold for cheap to a macho public entertainer that treats her like a bitch and she still clings to him in spite of several occasions to flea. Old, the guy misses her of course. The montage and the dubbing is very well done. Looks like Fellini was making films like walking in the park. So easy.

Fellini was a master from the beginning. This film is inventive, complex and strikes many chords amongst humans. The film sound track is all dubbed in two versions, italian and english. I watched the italian with subtitles. This is the kind of film that shows us lessons that are much better learned in cinema than in real life. The poor girl is sold for cheap to a macho public entertainer that treats her like a bitch and she still clings to him in spite of several occasions to flea. Old, the guy misses her of course. The montage and the dubbing is very well done. Looks like Fellini was making films like walking in the park. So easy.

Dark, comedic, and always entertaining, La Strada is a masterpiece of cinema with Shakespearean characters, masterful acting, and Fellini's quirky touch to make for one of the most unique experiences you'll ever sit through at the movies.

Extraordinarily haunting tragedy by Fellini.  Zampora (Anthony Quinn) "buys" the simple and sheltered Gelsomina to take her on the road as his carnival assistant.  Zampora is a brute who abuses and intimidates her, for which he feels remorse far too late.  Quinn is great as Zampora but Giulietta Masina's performance as Gelsomina is magnetic- superb as both performer and assistant, something about her expressions and movements, as one friend commented almost Chaplinesque, a silent film star for the talkies.  One to watch again soon.

Last week, I posted a review of the punk-rock movie Smithereens, stating that it's possible to make a good movie about inarticulate people who say only the dullest things if the underlying themes and subtexts are strong. La Strada is exactly that kind of movie. A brutish circus strongman takes on a faintly dimwitted woman-child. Neither of them are mental geniuses; no hyper-literate Aaron Sorkin rants here. But the basic universal themes of humanity run strong - the need for affection, security, respect, loyalty.

La Strada was Fellini's first break from the Neo-Realism that had dominated post-war Italian cinema. Zampano, Gelsomina and The Fool are not Everymen. They are dell'arte-ish archetypes thrust into a sad quest for survival in a poverty-stricken land. 

In fact, if you watch this movie as a realistic portrayal of events, it will lose you from the opening scene. Gelsomina, the woman-child, comes home to find that her older sister has died in the slavery/employ of some brutish circus beast, the circumstances of her sister's death come with no explanation, and that she has been sold into similar slavery/employ of this same brutish circus beast. So right away, we have a handful of grievous moral problems that are never addressed in this movie. This is just the life these people lead, and no one questions it. Hopefully this is not a real world in which people actually live. It is more comforting to view it metaphorically.

Giulietta Masina's performance is often compared to Chaplin, but I saw her much more as Harpo Marx, her clear, expressive face incapable of masking her moods, the picture of innocence, always reacting with utter honesty.

It was also interesting to see Richard Basehart, whom I only really had ever seen as the lead stiff in Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea, play such a lighthearted, effusive character.

Poignant. So well acted. A young woman is bought by a travelling entertainer and she falls for him but he is not capable of getting in touch with his feelings for her and yet they travel and perform together. Their dysfunctions inevitably lead to the conclusion. It is bittersweet to watch it happen but worth the ride.
Acted with plenty of nuance and almost fairytale-like in its story, this is a feel-sad call for human tolerance.

I wasn't expecting that horrible left turn. Fellini, you've broken my heart. But you've done it in such a fantastic way. La Strada is cinematic opera. The best film of the twilight era of Italian Neorealism. Also, if out of the clear blue, I can pick one of the characters I loved to hate the most in a movie, its Zampano. What an brute.
One of the most poignant and unforgettable road movies of all time, Fellini's La Strada is landmark film made all the more better by the presence of the marvelous character of Gelsomina.

Starring Anthony Quinn and Giulietta Masina. Anthony Quinn stars as Zampano, a brutish carnival strongman who takes to the road with his sidekick Gelsomina played by Masina, who embodies her character with a Chaplinesque quality that manages to be both whimsical and heartbreaking. Quinn makes his basically unlikable character into a rather tragic, sympathetic figure. This film won the first Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film. Directed by Frederico Fellini.

I finally had a chance to see Fellini's most personal masterpiece and glad I did. The Road is a tragic, emotionally powerful interplay of vagabonds Brute, Clown and Fool with a small brilliant cast each in career best performances. Masina and Quinn are unforgettable; Basehart unexpectedly perfect. The first winner of Oscar for Best Foreign Film among many other awards. There is wisdom here --the Brute ultimately destroys all but mostly himself in the end, and is left with only regret.

Giulietta Masina lends a captivating innocence - almost impossible not to love - to a Chaplin-like waif while Fellini breaks away from neorealism with this magical and whimsical circus fable/road movie that has a beautiful score by Nino Rota and an unforgettable ending.

Cornerstone of the Fellini body of work, this film left me , at first, completely lost. I think the first time i saw it, i felt depressed and was so angry with that son of a bitch Zampano, i could not get over how he treated the adorable Gelsomina. After studying he film for school though, it became clear the film is indeed fantastic and a real film experience. After watching it a few times, i have come to really enjoy it. Sometimes , films can be tough to get into but once you accept their reality , it's a fun trip.
Allegorical, parabolic, and flamboyantly acted - La Strada is filled with beauty, joy, tragedy, and sympathy.

This is the kind of movie that revolves around its characters and the interactions between them, but I just didn't care much for them. There are some interesting scenes and very interesting cinematography as a whole, but this movie wasn't really for me.
A dark and humanistic road movie that, if you let it sink in and affect you, has a devastating emotional impact.
Nice music, beautiful girl. Nice and smooth story telling!
It's the film that first brought international acclaim to Fellini.

Genius at work and a major influence on every major film maker who came after! Saw this as a child on late night tv with my Mom many years ago. She let me stay up late and we both wound up in tears. Loved Fellini ever since. A true master of movie making so full of life, cynicism mixed with a lovely blend of tenderness.
From a master Federio Fellini, An overwhelming humanism underscores the whole film and leaves its ultimate meaning up to interpretation. Simple and leeaves a lasting impression.
A brash strongman buys a girl to join his traveling circus. This almost-romance takes a sinister turn when we accidentally kills a trapeze artist in a brawl & she is the sole witness.

Well my first Fellini film wasn't what I expected. Luckily, La Strada is not a weird movie as the rest of them seem to be. It is actually very funny and quite bittersweet. It is about a woman called Gelsomina who has felt useless her entire life and finally she finds the charisma she didn't know she had while working with a circus artist, ZampanÃ². But because of his manhood and ego, he treats her as a useless person and then we can see the circus is not a great place to meet the world when someone's as naive as Gelsomina. Giulietta Masina (Federico Fellini's real wife) does a great performance.
a perfect film, this is the monomyth subverted, ruined into the shape of the actual world
Seemingly simple but actually It is a deep movie filled of metaphors, symbols and emotions.

A young and simple girl is sold off to a strong street circus man and falls in love with him regardless of the fact that he is a rude and cold man. The film follows the many adventures and misadventures they encounter along the way, and Fellini mixes lively comic sequences with emotional drama, building up to a tragic epilogue that seemed almost inevitable. In this film we find an inspired Fellini deal poetically with the circus, a reoccurring theme in his works, though this time he is not afraid to look at its negative and binding aspects. Anthony Quinn and Giulietta Masina in their respective roles are excellent and memorable and their uneasy chemistry adds genuinity and great human depth to the story.

La Strada is the film that marked Fellini's transition from Italian neo-realism, into his more famous and personal style. It's a very kinetic film that's very fun, in no small part due to the clownish grace of Giulietta Masina (Fellini's wife) and from Fellini's own background in the circus. La Strada holds a mythic quality to it even today, and It really does feel like a fairy tale, albeit one that doesn't have any semblance of a happy ending. A perfect introductory point into the the Italian director's grandiose filmography.
Introduction to Federico Fellini films I saw as a child. A Joyous Adventure. Another justification to become an eternal cinema lover of Foreign Language Films.
I can't believe it took me so many years to see this! It's stunning. Fellini is a genius.
One of the better Italian films, It's still a little too arty for the mainstream but the story is fairly logical. This film is full of interesting characters and scenarios.
Perfect. This is the first Fellini film I've seen that I really enjoyed. It's the kind of film I'd ideally like to make. By far my favorite of his.

When I watched it the first time 5 years ago, I understood it from a romantic view. Watching it again now, I perceived LIFE metaphors in everything. It is such a beautifully directed film, put together in a way that makes you wonder, laugh, get angry, and cry.
For once, Fellini's beautiful cinematography is outclassed by the powerful performances of all his actors- especially Giulietta Masina.
Great movie. Pretty depressing. I really liked it though. I just thought it dragged out at moments. It really pulls you in with the characters. It has a great story too. Heartbreaking.
It's hard to focus on a plot when the characters are too fake
Fellini's wife Giulietta Masina is absolutely incredible in this tale of a traveling carnival with a dark side. Heart felt and poignant.

I did not find any significant contribution in La Strada, there are a couple of key elements that helps the movie interpretation:
Gelsomina, the slow-witted woman is a symbol of soul, Zampano (Antoni Quinn) is a symbol of body, and the fool is a symbol of mind. The movie moves around these three characters, although it does not leverage the filmography to explain or provide anything about them. Compare this, for example, with Bergman's masterpiece "The silence".
The only thing I can give credit to in La Strada is the depiction of the drama between brutish Zampano and naive Gelsomina. Denied several times by Zampano, a man without any ethical or humanitarian value. The movie depicts how the simplicity of Gelsomina forms gradually the affection in Zampano which eventually changes him for the better.

A charming piece that is really made by the relationship between Gelsomina (who comes off as part Charlie Chaplin, part Harpo Marx and part Golden Retriever) and Zampano (who is far too gruff for anyone).

La Strada is one of the best movies right up there with Fellini's 8 1/2 and Nights of Cabiria and evokes the same kind of emotional response. I don't know which is more heartbreaking, the ending to La Strada or Nights of Cabiria. Giulietta Masina plays a Chaplinesque simple minded poor girl sold to the burttish Anthony Quinn to asist in his travelling strong man act. Along the way they meet The Fool, Quinn's old rival, who will offer Masina more than Quinn could. The acting here is as good as it gets and Quinn as Zampano. "The fool is hurt". Like I said, the ending is definitely one of the best along with Cabiria. A gem of a movie

Fellini's wife is an annoying bitch. How I know that? Because she plays the female lead in his La Strada. A really pit that I can't stand the naivety and numb nature of her Gelsomina because Anthony Quinn who plays the other leading character is plain awesome.
His Zampano is one of the greatest film characters I've seen on screen ever. Almost like a character from a Kurosawa film, he's both funny and brutal and right until the end we never exactly know if he's actually a good guy inside or why he just doesn't abandon Gelsomina.

Much of La Strada is a mystery, but the loose ends are, what it's essentially about. It's neither a melodrama nor a really character study, but just an excerpt of life, of a brute artist and a poor young girl who goes along with him for a certain distance. There's no tragic or happy ending, it just ends when their ways split again. I guess this is what life really looks like (at least more than Hollywood melodrama), the other thing is if I desire to watch a film about it.
If it has characters like Zampano, yes, give me more of it. With characters like Gelsomina I can live without these kind of films. La Strada, in the process, is somewhere in the middle - one brilliant character, an offbeat story but some very annoying details and of course Gelsomina as the big deal breaker.

Nevertheless, La Strada gets the old-master-bonus (which is the reason why I watched it in the first place) and you just have to acknowledge and admire Fellini's ability to play with comedy set pieces in this rather serious film.
Also, from what I've read, this is his most personal film and with some effort you can see references to his own life.
The best film of his I've seen, pretty much because it doesn't remind me of any other Fellini movie. http://superchicken46.blogspot.ca/2012/12/la-strada-1954-federico-fellini.html

La Strada is Federico Fellini's powerful film done in the Italian neorealist style and can be interpreted on many levels ranging from basic comedy to the metaphysical tragedy. The story is simple; daily existence for survival in a universe that does not care. The film suspends the viewer between the action of its characters and their stark environment and owes much to the black and white cinematographic technique of Otello Martelli and Carlo Carlini. Two scenes were particularly memorable to me; the first being the vast stretch of wind blasted wasteland surrounding the empty road as the two main characters, Gelsomina and Zampano, travel in their crazy motor caravan and the final scene with Zampano looking up from his drunken stupor on the sandy beach and recognizing the stars in the night sky for the first time but finding no place among them. This last scene is symbolic of man's separateness from the universe and his insignificance in it conveys more metaphysical horror than all of Bergman's films combined.
The best I've seen by Fellini
beautiful film. fantastic acting by Guiletta Masina
You will be smiling and crying the whole way through.
A Fellini tragedy and masterpiece
Wonderful, emotional, and moving. Brilliant construction and amazing acting.
I thought this was a very average film. There is no dramatic moment or massive plot to the film. It just plods along until it gets the end without really achieving a great deal.
Good depressing flick.
Sad and wonderful film.

La Strada is one of those rare instances of a Fellini film that doesn't hurl it's artistic beauty in your face. Along with Amarcord, La Strada is among my favorite films by Frederico Fellini (which is very few, considering I don't like 8 1/2 or The Clowns). It follows the story of an odd small town girl who's given to a brutish muscle man. It tells you a story of depression, guilt, and, above all, life. La Strada is one of the best portrayals of life I've ever seen in my life. 

Overall, La Strada, while not perfect, gets a 9/10 in my opinion.

Fellini masterwork. Athough not as good as Fellini's later works it's still a major advance in the "poetic cinema". It's a very sad movie, like the Beauty and the Beast in a way that was never put on the screen, and Giulietta Masina is just fantastic.

The film is gorgeous, with some memorable characters, namely Gelsomina. It doesn't end on a happy note, but you are still left satisfied with the story told, especially the lesson taught to Zampano, although it was all too late for him, and it is not certain that he learned from the experience. Masina is an absolute delight to watch, holding you captive with her face alone, beaming with love. The film is not for those looking for Hollywood drama and action, but for anyone who knows how it feels to be confused and in need of understanding about life's ways.

The main problem in Fellini's La Strada is the annoying main character. She was like an annoying Charlie Chaplin, I understand Fellini wanted a naive character but why annoying.
This is definently the weakest film of Fellini I've seen. The imagery was superb but the concept was not. A long sad story that ultimately led to something very disappointing.  You'd expect Fedrecio to have a trick up his sleeve, but he just made you feel like he had one.

The early Fellini film is one of his most accomplished. Fellini gets all the material in there that needs to, and exceeds thoroughly, but not everything he wants to, like he did with "8 1/2" , "Amarcord", "And the Ship Sails On", etc.. This film has a giant heart, and Fellini wants to put it where most people won't find anything. The result is more effective than I could've imagined before seeing this. Truly worthy chapter of an astonishing career.

A KVIFF screen of Fellini's black and white classic LA STRADA.

First I must refresh my memory to gather all the Fellini's I have watched so far. from 8 AND A HALF (1963, a 9/10), LA DOLCE VITA (1960, a 9/10) to AMARCORD (1973, a 8/10), so LA STRADA is the fourth one. The film has a direct exertion of pathos by coupling two disparate characters, an angelically miserable Gelsomina (Masina) and an uncivilised macho ZampanÃ² (Quinn), which may not pander to the New Wave trend at that time, but time proves its longevity and flags the upcoming career flourish which would verify Fellini as one of the most creative and intelligent film auteur in an historical scope. 

LA STRADA has a starkly primitive settings for the always-on-the-wheel couple, the gypsyish, footloose lifestyle seems to be endless and bleak along with the melancholic tunes, Gelsominaâ(TM)s hapless experience could melt any steel heart and her wide-eyed subservience is too heart-rending to even blame her; ZampanÃ², on another level, is a far cry from an evil soul, merely is a man with rudimentary desires and an irascible temper. 

 Giulietta Masina did an almost-perfect work to embody herself with all the ups-and-downs of a poor girlâ(TM)s misadventure both inwards and outwards, her Chaplin-esque clown mimicry and antics have a genuine comedic infusion to the views and by comparison, Quinnâ(TM)s chest chain-snapping stunt is over-used and outdated, but he has his own time, namely, the scenes of his final wail of grief are the salvation for him (a great solace for the audiences as well). Richard Basehart, his portrayal of âIl Mattoâ? is queerly vivacious, a sincere contrast to the adversity he would meet in due course. 

The cameras work miracles too, for example, the night shots of tightrope-walking among crowds has its enchanting depth of focus. Although the world in LA STRADA is a period I could never experience, and it is a more straightforward tale compared with Felliniâ(TM)s other oeuvres, but through the film I could potently sense a clear-minded manifesting of some most precious humility virtues which would also affect people under whatever conditions, to use a tear-jerking story to give hope, which is a marvelous achievement!
A moving film that can not forget.

Federico Fellini was an undeniably strange and quirky filmmaker both in his work and his image he presented to the world. So it almost seems natural that of all the films he wrote and directed this one has the characters he claims he can relate the most too. He based the character of Zampano on a man who worked in castrating pigs in his hometown of Rimini, the man supposedly got around with the local woman and got a mentally deficient peasant girl pregnant before leaving town and her to her fate. Meanwhile the film's co-writer Tullio Peninelli had wanted to write a similar screenplay after seeing a man and a woman traveling alone by wagon through the mountains, wanting to tell their life on the harsh road. So the two were merged and La Strada was born, filmed in various locations throughout Italy, winning the Academy Award for Best Foreign Film and being cited by Fellini as the film he felt the closest too. Though perhaps an obscure part of world cinema the film has made a mark in the musical world as well being cited as an influence and inspiration for Bob Dylan's "Mr. Tambourine Man", and the Kris Kristofferson penned hit "Me and Bobby McGee." So many years later how does La Strada really hold up though? A moving work or pretentious fluff? Let's take destined to die young look.

Our film is about brutish Zampano (Anthony Quinn, a really effective career defining performance and one often unfairly overlooked) a traveling circus strongman with a shady past who after buying a girl named Rosa for his assistant has returned to her hometown a year later with Rosa dead to buy her sister Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina, Fellini's wife who gives an equally moving but far different performance). Though she is a simple peasant girl suspected of having problems in the mind her mother accepts some money and sends Gelsomina on the road with Zampano to present and be a part of his act. Gelsomina has a childlike personality and though she is happy and curious at first quickly grows miserable with Zampano a horrible drunk and womanizer. She finds herself strangely attached to him however amidst all the trials of their relationship and the life they lead including being kicked out of a circus, encountering sad lonely people and eventually a horrible murder to terrible to handle.

What really amazes me about this movie is how fucking tragic it is, I mean there is nothing bittersweet or know hard lessons learned or anything at the end of this film it just cuts out on a world of bleak and utter despair. It's hardly the first tragedy but the heartbreaking destitute ending is certainly ballsy at a time where Hollywood was still making such upbeat optimistic films. As with a lot of Fellini's film the directing is excellent and top notch for its day, but though it has some strange imagery its much more rooted in terra firma than a lot of his other films lacking that dreamlike quality and in many ways making it a perfect starting point for Fellini newcomers. The performances main and supporting are all incredibly effective, especially Quinn who I'd argue gives the central performance and is especially incredible as Italian is not his first language. The story meanwhile is masterfully structured, La Strada is translated in English to the road and this movie effectively documents the trials and tribulations of a base, talentless one trick pony and his unfortunate and far too curious and big hearted assistant as the road and vagabond lifestyle breaks them down physically and emotionally until they are no more and than claims them body and soul. Perhaps a bit too late to be considered truly timely or relevant La Strada is still an effective and resonant story that can be related to all willing to give it a try and offers a glimpse into a world unfamiliar to American audiences than and now.

I loved La Strada, I think it's a really underrated masterpiece and it may not be the best but it remains my favorite Fellini film I've seen. I could find hardly a flaw in the entire film and it didn't feel dated in story or film-making in the slightest I found myself incredibly drawn into the whole well put together affair. Whether a fan of Italian cinema, Fellini in general or just plan movies I see no reason not to enjoy it and can't recommend the film highly enough if nothing else than for screen legend Anthony Quinn's greatest performance as Zampano and the gut wrenching incredibly moving ending. I can perhaps imagine the type of person this just wouldn't work for but I wouldn't want to be friends with them.
people rave about this but other than quinn's brutish performance i didn't find this that great
Solely for Giulietta Masina's perfomance. A female Chaplin.

Fellini pulls back the curtain and we see two types of men: the bully the who cares only to feed his senses; and the tight rope walker who challenges the beliefs of the bully.  Death claims the girl and tight rope walker leaving the bully to come to terms with his self made prison. what an honest portrayal of our lonely existence.
Rather enjoyable for an early road trip movie.

One of the all-time great films.  Stars Anthony Quinn and Giulietta Massina.  What a debut for her!  Hard to imagine who else could play that Gelsomina role.  This movie made director Fellini famous beyond Italy.  Yet La Strada is in the neorealist style, grimly realistic, in monochrome; NOT a "felliniesque" film.  That adjective is owing to later films in his career, like La Dolce Vita and Juliet of the Spirits.  Massina--by then Fellini's wife--stars also in that latter film, Juliet of the Spirits, in a totally different persona we might guess is much truer to her real self.

The two leads give great performances. The film however is ineffective at times and not as powerful as Nights of Cabiria. The circus scenes lag a little and the symbolism is very in your face. This is a good early effort from Fellini though as he would incorporate many stylistic features in his later films.

Not as Good as Amarcord, I think this was a little different for me coming into it because the two previous movies I saw from him which were Amarcord and And The Ship Sails On were more vignettish in nature and has strange surrealist moments. This one is played more as a tragedy. I think it's well written but I just felt something was off about this one. I did not connect with most of the characters in this film.
Fellini is amazing, this movie is touching and great
Human nature and existential longing reflected in gender roles, archetypes, and clashing of souls along the whimsical, turbulent road of life.
"The Road".... should have been named "The Ragdoll"

This interesting character study follows a thuggish circus strongman and his doormat-like girlfriend as they travel down the road together. Profound symbolism about the nature of codependent romantic relationships are at the forefront of this acclaimed drama by Federico Fellini. Some moments of this film are difficult to sit through, but that may be on account of the parallels that the viewer sees in their own life.

The female lead is awesome, but this first-ever Academy Award for  Foreign Film winner kind of sets the stage for the next 100 years of what is considered brilliant in a foreign movie: a weird penniless foreigner's metaphor-laden journey through a pointless life; a tragic human tale filled with tragedy plus humanity.  It's the pretension of those future works that annoys me more than this one specifically: Fellini shows signs of talent here, and he eventually ripened as a director, and, yes, for the 1950s, this is pretty outstanding.  I've simply far exceeded my tolerance for the stupider siblings of this kind of work.  It's worth remembering that film is a medium; having actors do and say things that no one cares about for two hours does not demonstrate mastery of the medium.  Shock, depth, vividness, boldness, integrity, and rounded skill are not achieved through sophomoric scripted trifles masquerading as thought-provoking moments.  Also, every good movie starts with a good script, but the script is not the end of production.  For a complete guide to proper moviemaking, see "Godfather" and "Godfather II."

Such an amazing film. Federico Fellini's first true landmark film, La Strada, established him as one of cinema's great directors almost immediately upon its release. The happy-go-lucky Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina) walks along the beach, where she is dragged back home by her young sisters. She learns that her older sister has died, and that she must take her place as assistant to the gruff, brutish Zampano (Anthony Quinn), a street performer who presents one simple trick that has gone utterly stale, but makes a living and that's all he cares about. While on the road, Zampano treats Gelsomina like dirt, yet they grow an attachment which only becomes apparent when it is too late. I adore this film's cinematography, which possesses some sort of greatness that I can't put my finger on. The acting is superb, Masina with her adorable facial expressions and naively optimistic manner, Quinn with his uptight, ape-like personality which is notoriously mocked by Richard Baseheart, "The Fool". All the rest of this masterpiece's charm, accompanied by Nino Rota's score which is as always, excellent makes this one of my favourite films.
What an outstanding performance by Anthony Quinn and Giulietta Masina in a heartbreaking story. Never seen a sadder face than Gelsomina's.

La Strada reminds me alot of Midnight Cowboy. There is a wall in the screenplay that prevents me from completely sympathizing and relating to the characters involved. But the performances are so amazing that it balances itself out. Anthony Quinn and Guilietta Masina are flawless. Fellini's direction is straightforward yet he manages to make nearly every shot a heartbreaking metaphor. That last scene will hurt your soul.

Giulietta Masina pulls you through the film with her open, honest presence, winning smile and sparkling eyes. The movie itself, while beautifully filmed, seems much ado about too little. I don't believe the film has the depth people attribute to it. It's a simple story with little happening much below the surface.
I liked this film better than the Dolce Vita, but they are both good.
A landmark film by Fellini boasting brilliant performances by Giulietta Masina and  Anthony Quinn!
This movie goes on the top of my Christmas list. I LOVE it.

Definitely a very good film with excellent performances from Quinn and Masina, but for me it wasn't quite at the level of "8 1/2" and "La Dolce Vita" though I can see how some people might prefer to those films.  Worth seeing for sure though.

Tuesday, November 1, 2011

(1954) La Strada
(In Italian with English subtitles)

DRAMA

  Self- absorbed muscle man(Anthony Quinn) and clown girl (Giulietta Masina and Fellini's real life wife) are travel performers and drift village to village showcasing their acts for money, but are also a couple, except that muscle man always abuses and humiliates her once the acts are over.  But while stumbling onto another village, they bump onto a harmless independent circus performer who're performers like them, and she becomes more accustomed to him with unfortunate results!

Although, I've read different interpretations about this film regarding it's symbolic overtones, I find that this film is more entertaining on paper than by watching it, since I thought it was rather predictable and strictly by the book which is a simplistic slice of life, similar to a "boy meets girl" type of storyline that can be more extreme if it was made today, perhaps taking the theme to new levels than settling for this one!  Oscar winner as "Best Foreign Language" film!

2.5 out of 4
The star of this film weirded me out. Kind of looked like a nutty Angela Lansbury. Other than that there is a lot to like and dislike here. Watch it and find out for yourself which is which.
Fellini's early masterpiece!

Translated as "The Road" this title makes more sense than you would think at first. It's not a road movie in the American vein, young people finding freedom and the big expanse of life. But it is a story of carnival performers on the road, and we see the landscape all over post-war Italy.If you haven't seen Italian movies from this period, or any other Fellini, you might have to adjust to a couple things. One is a lack of totally clear plot. It does make sense, but it will jump along in little episodes that seem incidental. I think what this means is that the important things in life are incidental, and that it brings the viewer into the ordinary flow of these two or three lives. There is a touch of surrealism now and then, which adds to the strange feeling. The photography is simple but beautiful enough, and the scenery, every changing, adds to the sense that we are sweeping across a whole time to capture it and make it cohesive. The sound is odd, all dubbed in later (voices and musicians playing instruments, everything), and it is so obviously out of synch it again makes the experience dreamlike and bizarre. If you can't get used to that you might just write it off as low-budget.
Of course, avoiding the main point until the end, this is a movie that gets into your heart. It's about a mean man and a sweet submissive girl who ends up being his wife, by default. Neither is a paradigm of movie beauty--Anthony Quinn at his roughest as Zampano, a circus strong man, and Giulietta Masina a tiny Gelsomina with a mime-like face that makes her the sad clown of the movie, very sympathetic. By the end, when Zampano is still seemingly unredeemable, we follow his every move and every twitch on his face because we are drawn into the tragedy of his life, even though it seemed avoidable all along. He's just that uncouth, untamed kind of man, and as much as he deserved to be made fun of (as another character does), he receives the empathy of Gelsomina.If you can step into the style and go with the odd flow of the scenes, you might find this a flawless film. Sometimes the best art is idiosyncratic, as this is. There are no inconsistencies, the feeling of the movie evolves and is fully grasped all through, and we are allowed to watch with wonder and understanding. Because we have seen these people before, in parts, and in ourselves. That's why it matters.

"La Strada" is in Federico Fellini's top five best movies for me, as well as Giulietta Masina's best performance in his movies so far. Sweet and naive Gelsomina (Masina) is born in a poor family, and in a desperate attempt to get ten-thousand lire, her mother sells her to rough circus performer Zampanò (Quinn). Gelsomina hates him, but she enjoys the circus life, and appreciates all that her owner has taught her. When the two are picked up by a bigger deal circus, Gelsomina meets Il Matto (The Fool) (Basehart) and after a few meetings, she falls for him. Too bad the triangle brings doom for the three. "La Strada" is one of Fellini's masterpieces, and since I prefer his black-and-white '50's films to his strange '60's and later surrealist movies, I knew I had to see this movie considering how many few "normal" movies he has. Truly, this is one of his most memorable movies. The message, the score, and especially the cinematography capture the essence of everything this movie is about, and Fellini does not make anything in this movie un-enjoyable or trite. Masina has been called the female Chaplin for how she uses facial expressions and body language to show what she is trying to say, and indeed she does this and makes a very very touching performance, and outdoes the rest of the cast (even though Quinn and Basehart are superb) just by doing her role so subtly. No matter what, you can feel the emotions that she presents, and in the meantime gives us one of the most sympathetic performances of all time. The BAFTA nod is well deserved. "La Strada" is an excellent movie that is not only dark, but is one of the most touching films I've ever seen. Highly recommended.
Powerful emotional movie with extremely touching actors. Guilietta Masina is absoluetly incredible !

From the beginning to the end my eye were glued. Arguably Fellini's first 'Fellinieasque' movie. The acting is outstanding, Fellini's directing coming from a planet we have yet to discover, and the photography is outstanding. What is most striking is the carnival and its cast of characters. I don't want to give much away but there's conflict, a ship full of symbolism, and jealousy. It's not as surreal as Fellini's later works but it shows what is to come in 'La Strada' one of the master's greatest achievements in his post neo-realist stage. Is there such a thing as watching too much Fellini? If so, commit me to the ward.
best fellini film behind nights of cabiria
If you can ignore a few major plot-holes herein, I guess you'll enjoy the tragic journey (which hardly leads anywhere) of a girl in  this classic movie.

There it is: the role Giulietta was born to play - the Chaplin-esque waif that implacably breaks our hearts at the end, due to the mismatch between purity and brutishness which collide in a twist of faith during the desolation of a winter. One of Fellini's best and simplest masterpieces, from an era when he had retained all the simplicity you need to invoke to create something wrenching without resorting to cheap melodrama or stylistic pomp. Anthony is just what he ought to be, while Nino Rota's melody underlines the tragic circusmtances to create a haunting undertone to the dauntless characters en route to their doom: as the brute sits on the beach, staring into the wordless sea, Fellini's triumph of elements creates history. Or at least something America can never produce.

You really get a glimpse into Fellini's heart in this film. It's so gorgeously shot, and gorgeously written that you can't help but leave the movie with a huge pallet of emotions. The characters are brilliantly crafted, and equally brilliantly acted, that they stick with you long after the film has ended. Not the masterpiece of cinema which 8 1/2 is, but vastly more heartfelt.
Yet another poetic piece of Italian neorealism, but in the Fellini flavor..

Superlative acting....Guiletta Masina is absolutely scintillating....a face like an artichoke she might have been...but with that she delivered her finest performance ever......Anthony Quinn was the perfect cast as ZAMPANO.....a life on the  road and the different emotions that come up along the way.....

Fellini as always directs an incredible film.  This one makes us stop and think about the decisions we make and why we make them?  Do we choose things because we thought it out or because we just react?  Masina is fantastic as Gelsomina and Quinn is superb as the deplorable Zampano who reacts and doesn't think.  Innocence is shown very well as Gelsomina is given multiple chances to leave Zampano and do something else but she feels she must stay with him and that she has a purpose by helping him.  It has to be seen to be fully understood and I think the beauty in it is different people may relate to different characters and pull out different things - this flm leaves much more for the audience.
A deeply moving and unforgettable  film. Federico Fellini's timeless classic. Great performances by Giulietta Masina and Anthony Quinn. Must watch.

"La Strada" is a character-driven film about a foul-tempered circus performer and his assistant.  The success of the entire film is contingent upon the audience falling in love with Gelsomina's quirky personality... and though I was doubtful at first, she won me over.  Giulietta Masinaâ(TM)s facial expressions often reminded me of Harpo Marx, not needing extensive dialogue to portay her emotions as her expressive eyebrows told her story.  Anthony Quinn is marvelous (and monstrous) as Zampano, the heartless strongman who constantly rejects Gelsomina.  Punctuated by a beautiful musical theme by Nino Rota, La Strada will tug at your heart and make you thankful for acceptance in this world.
Hard to describe, totally immersive movie experience

My first Fellini movie, but definitely not my last. La Strada is an amazing film. At times it is very fun to watch and at others it is almost painful. It brings about an array of emotions that change throughout the entire movie.
Fellini working his comic,tragic, beauty thing.

What a surprise of the Fellini's early movies. I don't even get his later movie. the carefree girl follows the traveling entertainer who is a rough guy. a few times, the girl can leave in his hand, but she didn't do it, because the man is her host. One IQ less girl knows what is duty, but that guy ? he killed a man and even covered the accident. he fall away the girl on the road. After a few years, he knows the girls was died by him, he feel compunction. One more thing, "after many years", maybe many movies will show up on the screen. however, La Strada shows up "after many years" by the man asking the woman. And I like it.
Charming, moving, and beautiful in a slightly over the top way.
So, it's my second Fellini, but I still don't see the big deal? I'm left cold by La Strada.
Simplistic, beautiful, and touching.

Giulietta Masina's Gelsomina is one of the most quirky female characters I have seen since Amelie and she is simply delightful. I was almost convinced that Fellini would give a happy end but he just ain't that sort of guy!
Sad, touching... a "must have" by Fellini.
wow famous actress have good smile ( Giulietta Masina )
A film so lovely, it inspired the naming of my kitty. Also, I have dedicated my life to performing negligible feats of strength.

La Strada '54 (The Road)!

Please help me find words of appreciation for this grand masterpiece. La Strada is an art of cinematography work, and art-direction.

I think I just found a reason to live. I have always liked Road-Films like The Grapes of Wrath '39 and so on.

I have learned most intelligent codes of life from this marvelous film, directed by Federico Fellini, Fellini has crossed the boundaries of crafting cinematic-success, after making this grand 'La Strada', what a performance from Giulietta Masina, she has shown both characters of being funny, while she was needed to be and dramatic, when was needed. 

What to speak about Anthony Quinn, I love Zampano (Anthony Quinn). He has shown both honor and redemption, from his unbelievable performance, his ending performance as being drunk and crying at beach; is one of most dramatic scenes in the history of Cinema, probably as powerful as the ending scene of Gone With The Wind '39 directed by Victor Fleming, starring Clarke Gable and Vivien Leigh. 

I adore this movie a lot and I salute Academy Awards by honoring it with first Best Foreign Language Oscar Award.
Less pretentious than some Fellini but i still prefer La Dolce Vita, Masina though is brilliant in this.
